MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Meeting with British Prime Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if any firm arrangement have been made with regard to the date, venue and agenda of his next meeting with the British Prime Minister.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In accordance with normal practice, arrangements for my next meeting with the British Prime Minister will be announced simultaneously here and in London shortly in advance of the meeting.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach wish to comment on persistent and apparently authentic newspaper reports to the effect that the next meeting between himself and the British Prime Minister will not take place before the summer of this year?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I have no intention of commenting on such reports. The only thing I can do is to reiterate what was said at the time of the last meeting, that there would be a further meeting between us in the coming months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach will recall he told the Dáil on 20 November that a further meeting would take place between himself and the British Prime Minister — he attached great importance to this fact — early in the new year. Does he wish to comment on the fact that that statement has already been proved to be untrue?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I would simply say it has not been proved to be untrue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Can the Taoiseach tell us now that the meeting is likely to take place within the next few months? Nobody in the House would ask for the time, date and so on because of security reasons but surely the Taoiseach can tell us if these persistent reports that the meeting will not now take place before the summer and after the local elections in Northern Ireland are true of false?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The meeting will take place in the next few months. I do not understand the sources that suggested the postponement of the meeting. That is not the case. No date had been fixed and there is no question of postponement. The meeting will take place in the coming months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Is it not obvious to all that the statement that the meeting would take place early in the new year can no longer be complied with and that to that extent the Taoiseach misled the House and the public? Will he not be honest enough and man enough to admit that this meeting will not take place before the local elections in Northern Ireland and that these much vaunted talks between himself and the British Prime Minister are going nowhere?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is argument.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I can confirm that the latter statement of the Deputy is not correct. With regard to the meeting, it will take place——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: When?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: ——in the coming months. There has been no change. A date was not fixed at the time. Discussions are proceeding and the meeting will take place at the appropriate time in the next few months.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 2. Deputy Allen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach confirm that the meeting will not take place before the local elections in Northern Ireland? Will he confirm or deny that fact?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I am in no position to confirm that fact because no date has been fixed and I am not in a position to make any statement with regard to that. I have told the Deputy a meeting will take place in the next few months at an appropriate time. At the end of his previous supplementary——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I suggest that the Taoiseach is misleading the House on this important matter. He made a great fuss of the fact that a meeting would be held early in the year between himself and the British Prime Minister. That is not now going to happen. The Taoiseach is not man enough to admit it is not going to happen——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not a question. I have called Question No. 2.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach will not admit that the meeting will not take place until after the local elections in Northern Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I have told the Deputy that is not the case. No decision has been taken that a meeting will not be held in the early part of this year——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Two negatives.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: From lack of information, the Deputy is unintentionally misleading the House on that point.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I called Question No. 2.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Talks on Nicaragua.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will make a statement on his recent discussions with the vice-President of Nicaragua, Senor Ramirez.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: It would not be appropriate for me, nor is it the established practice, to disclose publicly details of confidential discussions of this nature. Senor Ramirez's visit here was part of a tour of west European countries and, as the Deputy will appreciate, my discussions with him concentrated on the current crisis and prospects in the Central America region including the situation in his own country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach concerned with the damage being done to the political and economic system in Nicaragua because of the United States-backed Contra campaign? Has he any plans to raise that at the highest level with the United States authorities?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: It is relevant. Will the Taoiseach also raise the question of the withdrawal of the United States from the Contadora process and from the hearing at the World Court?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am ruling that that is clearly a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: It is relevant and it is a fair question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 3.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I do not belong to the same party and perhaps I may be permitted to ask a question. Will the Taoiseach indicate if the vice-President of Nicaragua made the same point to him as he made to me, namely, that all the Nicaraguans were seeking at this stage was a resumption of talks between themselves and the United States?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I do not want to go into the question of what was discussed in detail but it is well known that the Nicaraguan Government are anxious to have a resumption of those talks and they are also concerned that the Contadora process should proceed. It is our position, with the other members of the Ten, that we favour the continuation of the Contadora process which we support strongly. We hope that the meeting that failed to take place in the past few days can be organised as soon as possible for a constructive discussion of the issues raised in the Contadora act.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: In view of the Taoiseach's reply to Deputy Haughey's question, two standards seem to apply in this House — one for the Leader of the Opposition and one for Deputy backbenchers.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Allen will resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: I just asked the same question——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Allen will resume his seat now. If Deputy Allen is casting any reflection on the Chair, he will withdraw that at once.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: I will withdraw it, but I cannot understand how the same question could be allowed. Has the Taoiseach any plans at present to open up diplomatic relations with not only Nicaragua but the whole Central American region, even at consular level?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In certain countries we have honorary consuls, but there are no plans for diplomatic relations with the countries in question. There are financial constraints and limitations on the range of diplomatic relations that we can organise. We are not at present contemplating a move of that kind which would be costly in relation to that area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach reconsider the position in relation to diplomatic relations since relations at consular level would not be too expensive for this country?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Let me make a distinction. There is consular representation, which does not constitute formal diplomatic relations. We have honorary consuls in various areas, and that is open to consideration. The question of our honorary consular representation is under active review at present, not particularly in that part of the world but generally. No doubt that review covers Central America, but I have no details of it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: The party which visited Nicaragua recently brought out a report containing certain recommendations. Has the Taoiseach any plans to pursue these recommendations with our partners within the EC?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: How that question arises out of the question on the Order Paper is not clear.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: I presume that the Taoiseach discussed matters such as these with Senor Ramirez when he was in Dublin?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a totally different question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Come over here and we will look after you.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if, in view of the unavailability of statistics for emigration in 1983 and 1984 and in view of the Government's inability to identify present trends in emigration, he will initiate an investigation into emigration patterns since the last census with the assistance of second and third level colleges, foreign embassies and Irish associations particularly in Britain.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will give special responsibility to a Minister of Government or a Minister of State to consider all aspects of the alarming increase in emigration; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 3 and 4 together. I do not accept that there has been an alarming increase in emigration. The evidence from the CSO is that their best estimate of net emigration in the period April 1981 to April 1984 is an average of 6,000 a year, and their best estimate suggests that net emigration in the year to April 1984 was less than in the year to April 1983.

The most recent information available from the school leavers survey and the Higher Education Authority's report does not suggest a high level of emigration. For example, it is estimated that, of over 62,000 school leavers in 1983, only 1,500 had emigrated in the following year. Fewer than 500 primary degree recipients in the same year and about 250 other third level award recipients are estimated to have left — many of them for further study or training.
The Deputy's contention that emigration has commenced at a substantial rate does not receive any support from these data.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach honestly believe the figure he has just read out, of 6,000 people per year emigrating from the country at present, in the light of all the experience and all the estimates coming from very worthwhile sources? Let me quote two such sources to him. One is the figure given by the Irish Association in England in “Today Tonight” during the week of 30,000 people and the second is The Irish Times today which contains a very good article emanating, I believe, from the American Embassy indicating that 55,000 holiday visas were given out last year and the estimate of the people in the embassy is that 5,000 of those are remaining in the US in an illegal capacity. In view of those facts will the Taoiseach stop giving us this statistic which he had given to the House already on 22 January? It is totally inaccurate, and I put it to him that there is now a very serious problem with regard to the number of people ——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy should confine himself to asking questions.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I cannot accept the Deputy's conclusion. I accept that the best estimate of net emigration furnished by the CSO is subject to a margin of uncertainty and is based on data which are necessarily incomplete and is only a kind of census so that we can get an accurate assessment of the inter-censual emigration. A problem exists in assessing that and it is necessary perhaps to look to other information. The best information we have, which is the most solid, is the figures from the sampling of school leavers and the HEA's report which gives us a picture of the number of people emigrating in the year after completing their education. These figures show a low proportion involved, in the case of school leavers 1,500 out of 62,000. Also the CSO tell me that the numbers contacting various Irish——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: It is a laugh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: There is the problem the Taoiseach had better address himself to.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: To say that the labour survey I am talking about and the statistics of the HEA are a laugh makes a laugh of the Opposition. At least they are reasonably solid data, not speculative in character. The only other information I can add is that the CSO tell me that the numbers contacting Irish societies and Irish centres in Britain are quite small and, in so far as they exist, are a very inadequate basis for measuring emigration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Has the Taoiseach or any member of Government been in contact with the embassies — US, Canadian, Australian or British — to ascertain the veracity of what Deputy Fahey has confirmed? I have the same information directly from those embassies. Secondly, has the Taoiseach been directly in contact with, for instance, the Federation of Irish Societies in Britain who will confirm to him that the figures he has trotted out here from the HEA or whatever are just a laugh, as I said? Is the Taoiseach not aware that the people in Britain who are dealing with this and trying to cope with it are so alarmed that they are seeking a discussion with him and probably with the Opposition to see how we can provide for the welfare of young people? In the light of those facts would the Taoiseach not acknowledge that Government have a special responsibility to young people? In the light of those facts, will he not consider giving that special responsibility to some member of Government to ensure that those who are forced by the policies of this Government to go are at least properly prepared and advised in advance? At this point they are not. If the Taoiseach wants to ignore those facts he can do so, but they are facts.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a long statement.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I can tell the Deputy that the CSO state that the numbers contacting various Irish societies and Irish centres in Britain are quite small.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Has the Taoiseach been in contact with them? I have.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I will pass on to the Deputy information coming from the relevant source, the CSO, in regard to that. As I have said, the figures in respect of school leavers and those leaving higher education supply the only solid and reliable data we have and do not confirm what is being alleged.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennecy Mr. O'Kennecy
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach's own backbenchers will tell him about the applications they get every day.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dukes Mr. Dukes
Speaker.P: They are the ones who explain what you could not understand.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: We must confront not this issue being put forward by the Opposition but the fact that there are not opportunities for emigration. People are not emigrating and we must try to cope with this problem at home. It is here in the form of unemployment. That is the issue, and to try to turn it into emigration to evade the issue of domestic unemployment is very foolish.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: In view of the projections in Building on Reality, 1985-1987 and the provisions in 1985 for unemployment of 217,500 and the fact that in January this year the number exceeded 234,000, may we take it that continuing and increasing emigration is an essential element for the realisation of the Government's plan Building on Reality?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: No.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Is it not clear that unless there is a continuing drain of emigration the figures in the Government's plan and the provision for unemployment in the budget expenditure are totally unreasonable——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a speech on some document.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: ——and that the Government are depending totally on continuing emigration to realise their projections?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy once more and regrettably is displaying his ignorance. If he had read Building on Reality he would know that the estimates on unemployment are based on one of two sets of alternative projections by demographic experts in respect of emigration, that the lower estimate of emigration was chosen and is the basis of that report, an estimate which involves in the next two years a net emigration rate of 5,000 per annum. That may turn out to be right or otherwise but it is the basis on which the plan was prepared. It does not require, provide for or include in any form a high level of emigration as the Deputy would know if he had bothered to read the report rather than making a fool of himself here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: The figure in the plan is 220,000.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling on Deputy Fahey and I am asking Deputy O'Kennedy to resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach should read his own document. The unemployment of 220,000 as projected in that document is now 234,000.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Kennedy is ignoring the Chair. I have called Deputy Fahey who has also tabled a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: Before the young people of Ireland begin regarding all of us politicians with total cynicism, will the Taoiseach put away that document in which he reads that between 5,000 and 10,000 people are emigrating? I am asking him in all sincerity to take up the request in my question because I have contacted the embassies and the Irish associations in Britain——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Has the Deputy a question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: —— and in the US and all of them have agreed that there are now 30,000 people leaving Ireland each year.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is making a speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: In the light of this figure, would the Taoiseach contact the embassies abroad and also the second and third level colleges who are aware of how many of their students have left the country and would he accept the figures given particularly in The Irish Times and in the “Today Tonight” programme by the people on the ground, so to speak, especially those in Irish associations in Britain? Would the Taoiseach initiate an investigation for the purpose of establishing the number of people who are leaving the country?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a speech, a good speech perhaps but a speech nevertheless.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: The reason I believe the Taoiseach should change his stance——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It is absurd for the Deputy to call this a question.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I shall try to extract a question from what the Deputy has been saying and to answer it if I am allowed to do so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: That type of flippancy ill becomes the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: There is nothing flippant about the subject in question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach was not so good on television the other night.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: With 600 people leaving the country this week, would the Taoiseach disregard the document he has quoted from and begin a proper investigation into the numbers leaving?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In reply to that interesting speech, I would point out first that school leavers are contacted and that there is a survey, a document with which the Deputy must be familiar if he has any serious interest in this subject, that shows that for the most recent 12 months period available — that is in respect of those leaving school in mid-1983 — only 1,500 of the 62,200 had emigrated. The Deputy may find that unpalatable.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: It is not true.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: That is the one piece of information we have from that source about school leavers. It is based on a sampling technique which is reasonable and appropriate to give an accurate result with a certain limited margin of error. The other information we have and which is practical is the Higher Education Authority Report which gives specific figures for the numbers who have left. There is no point in the Deputy producing a mythical figure of an emigration rate of 30,000. That simply shows a degree of ignorance and irresponsibility which is inappropriate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: It is not a mythical figure.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: While the Deputy's figure is obviously absurd there are genuine difficulties in assessing the precise level of net emigration between censuses. I have said very carefully that the best estimate for the past three years is 6,000 per year. The method by which the figure has to be arrived at is a method which is uncertain and unsatisfactory and I would not place undue reliance on it. The better figures are those we can get from specific surveys such as the school leavers survey and the Higher Education Authority Report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach accept the word of the American Embassy that between 5,000 and 6,000 illegal emigrants have left this country for America alone in the past 12 months?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: If the Americans deport that number of people to Ireland, I will accept that figure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: One can only think of Nero as the Taoiseach continues.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: If the Taoiseach insists on ignoring reality that is his business but in regard to his comment on Building on Reality, would he like to tell the House how, other than by way of emigration, he can reconcile the projection in that document of an unemployment figure of 220,000 at the end of 1984 when the figure in that respect at the end of January 1985 was 234,000 which the Government underpinned by way of provision for an average of 217,500 in 1985?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This is a debate on emigration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: I am referring to the Taoiseach's document. How can the Government achieve their projection unless they are relying on continuing emigration to reduce the number on the live register?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The relevance to emigration is slightly remote but let us consider the facts. The estimate in Building on Reality for the level of unemployment at the end of 1984 was 220,000, seasonally adjusted. The actual figure was 221,000 seasonally adjusted. The Deputy should not try to fool the House or the people by producing figures that are not comparable with each other, by producing figures that are not seasonally adjusted and comparing them with figures that are seasonally adjusted. His tongue-in-cheek approach of trying to fool people will not get him anywhere. As I have said, the future projections of unemployment are based on the projections for employment set out in the plan and on the low figure of the alternative figures offered by the demographic experts. They involve net emigration of 5,000 in the next two years.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I must move on to Question No. 5. I have been more than generous on that last question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: How can a figure of 234,000 be adjusted to 221,000?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Kennedy is shouting down the Chair and that is very unbecoming, to put it at its mildest. The Chair is giving a discretion under Standing Orders.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: What the Taoiseach is saying is very worrying.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cattle Hide Exports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the value and quantity of cattle hides exported from this country in 1982, 1983 and 1984; and the value and quantity of hides cured at home in the above years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State of the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett, Dún Laoghaire) Minister of State of the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett, Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State of the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett,
Speaker.P: Dún Laoghaire): I propose to circulate a statement giving the information requested by the Deputy. Following is the statement:
1. Exports of cattle hides

MainHeading.P: 2. The estimated numbers of cattle hides cured and sold as such, by the tanning industry in the years 1982, 1983 and 1984 (January-September) were as follows: 1982, 703, 200; 1983, 744, 400; 1984 Jan-Sept, 517, 600. Information on value is not available. These estimates exclude (a) hides cured and further processed into leather by the same firm and (b) hides cured by establishments not in the tanning industry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister think that the House and the country are properly served by a statistics office which can produce accurate figures for cattle hides but which must rely on best estimates in terms of people?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: That is a fair question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 6, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Are we to hear about Mostek now?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - CIE Equipment Expenditure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the expenditure for 1984 on (a) mainline carriage building and (b) signalling equipment up to 31 December 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Communications (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.P: Expenditure on mainline carriage building during 1984 amounted to £14 million while expenditure of £4.5 million was incurred on signalling.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Independent Local Radio.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications when the proposed Independent Local Radio Authority will be in operation and in a position to issue licences.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the estimated cost of establishing the Independent Local Radio Authority; the estimated annual cost; and if he has included this cost in estimates for 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications if his Department have obtained premises for the Independent Local Radio Authority; the location of these premises; and the cost of rental or purchase.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications if he will estimate the total number of independent local radio stations to be established under proposed legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications if he will approve the establishment of an independent local radio news and sports service to cater for independent local radio stations.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minisster for Communications if his plans for local radio will allow local authorities to apply for licences to the Independent Local Radio Authority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12 together.

It would not be appropriate, in advance of legislation, to make provision in the Estimates for an independent authority but the Deputy will appreciate that this would not prevent the Authority from being established in the current year. Neither have premises been acquired. As I indicated some time ago my intention is that the Authority's headquarters should be in Cork, but it will be a matter for the Authority to acquire whatever premises they need.
As many of the Deputies' questions anticipate the legislation about to be introduced, it would be better to wait until the legislation is before the House before I answer these questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: I should be entitled to a few supplementaries on this number of questions.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Will the Deputy deal with one first?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: Could I ask the Minister the reason for the long delay in bringing forward this legislation? I would remind the Minister that he has been in that office for the last two and a half years and in that time this legislation has not been brought forward. Could I ask the background for this long delay?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will appreciate, there have been great difficulties about this legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: That is true.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: One of the main difficulties is that it went before the legislation committee and took much longer than anticipated. That delayed the process by at least eight months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: In relation to the number of stations, the Minister is on record as saying that seven stations would be adequate. The Minister has had quite some mileage, newspaperwise, on this whole issue, without giving any factual statement at all. Could he indicate if the statement of the Minister of State, Deputy Nealon, as reported in the national newspapers, in relation to 30 stations would be in line with the Minister's statements that he is in favour of seven stations? Could he give some indication of the number of stations that he anticipates?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I would be happy to clarify the position for the Deputy. The Minister of State at my Department, in answer to a question from the legislative committee, said then that the frequency spectrum technically could carry about 30 stations of different orders of magnitude. A misunderstanding got abroad from that that what the Minister of State said was that there would be 30 stations. Subsequently, in order to clarify the position I said that while the frequency spectrum could carry up to 30 stations, if we went by the IBA standards in Britain the figure would be rather less.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The Minister of State put his foot in it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There are all sorts of criteria, including the listenership criteria. For the information of the House, because of negotiations that have been more or less brought to a conclusion, the frequency spectrum available would be much larger. We will now have five national VHF networks available to us, compared with three hitherto. We will also have other regional VHF networks available to us. The technical possibilities for the number of stations will be greatly increased.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: The Minister has stated that he is not in a position to include this in the 1985 Estimate because the legislation has not been passed by the Dáil and I accept that. Would this require a Supplementary Estimate for his Department and will he indicate if he has made some estimates? He has studied the matter for the last two and a half years and I feel sure that his advisers and his Department have advised him of the estimated cost to the Department of setting up stations or organising the Independent Local Radio Authority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Of course, some exercises have been done on possible costs, but I cannot anticipate legislation yet to be enacted by this and the other House. The costs that would be involved depend very much on the outcome of that legislation and the time element.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: It is proposed to locate the Independent Local Radio Authority in Cork. This is naturally welcomed by the Cork Deputies, but is a very small replacement for Ford's, Dunlop's and the other major factories which have been closed. Nevertheless since it will be located in Cork, would the Minister not think it appropriate, in view of the urgency of the legislation, that his Department could be in a position to have earmarked suitable premises for leasing or purchasing when the time comes?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The Deputy can take it that my Department will take every necessary step, and in good time, to make sure that the Independent Local Radio Authority, when set up, will be able to function pretty well immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: In view of his replies to Deputy Leyden, could I ask the Minister if the heads of the Bill are ready, if such heads have been before the Government and if they are agreed by the Government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The position is that the Government have not only considered the heads of the Bill, but have almost completed consideration of the entire Bill. I hope to be in a position to make an announcement on the legislation very shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: Could the Minister now state to the House how many stations he envisages, following on the additional frequencies available to him?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I do not envisage any particular number of stations. That should be properly a matter for the Independent Local Radio Authority when it is set up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: Did the Minister not state very recently that in his view there should be quite a number of commercial stations and at the same time quite a number of community stations? If that be the case, how does he envisage the community stations licensing themselves?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I think that the Deputy is probably misconstruing what I said. I said that I anticipate a certain development. That is not to say that that will not take place — my guess is as good as anybody else's in this case. I imagine that we are likely to have different types of radio stations, some very local indeed and perhaps others more widespread. As the Deputy will be aware, there are a number of pirate stations in operation which are completely community stations, in that they are run by community interests and not for profit. There are other stations which are only profit-orientated. I cannot be precise and cannot anticipate how this will develop. I imagine it likely that we will have some sort of two-tier system.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I shall allow Deputy Reynolds a final supplementary and Deputy Gallagher a supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: Surely the Minister is trying to mislead the House when he says that he is not in the guessing game? If heads of the Bill have been agreed by Government, surely he knows exactly the position and the guidelines which have been agreed at Government level to put to the local authorities on which they will base their assessment of the whole situation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Just to clarify the point, whatever legislation this House may pass will not dictate necessarily the number of stations which will emerge. either at the very small community level or wider, regional or local level. It is very hard to anticipate exactly how many stations are likely to emerge.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: In other words, the Government have not agreed their guidelines to give to the local Independent Local Radio Authority when it is set up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Michell Mr. J. Michell
Speaker.P: I have already told the House that the Government have almost completed their consideration of the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: Has it taken two and a half years almost to complete that consideration?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Would there be any ideological problems?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Can the Minister guarantee to the House that the independence enjoyed by Radio na Gaeltachta will not be interfered with in any way when these new stations are being set up?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I call Deputy Allen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: Could I ask the Minister——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I have called Deputy Allen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: How does the Minister propose to deal with the present illegal stations when the time comes to entertain applications?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Capital punishment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is also a separate question. I intend to introduce two pieces of legislation simultaneously, one dealing with illegal broadcasting and one making arrangements to set up legal local radio.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A final supplementary from Deputy Leyden.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: Would the Minister make a more specific statement in regard to the position of pirate radio stations? He has made many statements about these stations over the years. There is some ambiguity about his position, as he is well aware. He should put on the record of this House his views as Minister on the future of existing pirate stations, whether they will be free to apply for licences.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: It is Government policy that we should phase out illegal radio stations as we make provision for legal local radio. That is what we intend to do.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 13.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Will the skull and crossbones appear on the new flag, at the top left hand corner?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - An Post Finances.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the total allocation to An Post under section 29 (1) of Postal and Telecommunications Services Bill, 1982, for capital works in 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the total transfer of funds to An Post in 1984 for current expenditure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 13 and 14 together.
No contribution to finance capital works was made to An Post during 1984, but a current expenditure grant of £5 million was made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: In the Posts and Telecommunications Services Bill we made provision for capital payments to An Post.

MainHeading.P: The Minister should be aware of the rundown condition of many of the buildings that An Post obtained from the former Department of Posts and Telegraphs. The Minister's explanation is unacceptable. I regret that the Minister made no capital allocation to An Post for 1984 and I would ask the Minister to indicate now if he proposes to make a capital allocation for capital works to An Post in 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: While there is a provision in the Posts and Telecommunications Act, 1983 for the payment of capital grants to An Post I did not feel it necessary to make a capital grant available during 1984. There will be provision in the Estimates this year for a capital grant to An Post.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: The post office and sorting office in Cork city, which I inspected as Minister of State and found it to be in an appalling condition, would require major capital expenditure. Will the Minister indicate if he has received an application from An Post for capital works in 1985 and will he indicate the proposed location of the proposed capital expenditure?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: That has been repaired.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I am grateful to Deputy Allen for putting Deputy Leyden right in relation to Cork post office. There will be provision this year for a capital grant of £4 million to An Post but I do not have the details as to its expenditure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that An Post is setting about its task of being a viable commercial operation——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: If the Ceann Comhairle would wait, I will relate it to the answer the Minister gave. In view of that fact, will the Minister not agree that it is important to provide An Post with both the capital and current grants that they need in this intervening period?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Everybody has been greatly impressed by the success of An Post since its establishment. I am happy with the state of An Post and I am happy that they have adequate resources to do the job.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: It would be appropriate for the Minister to outline the proposed expenditure of the £4 million for 1985. The Minister should be informed as to the expenditure. In relation to the An Post fleet, was any allocation made for it in 1984?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: They are very detailed questions and if the Deputy tables them I will answer them.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 15. please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Did the Minister in his reply mention a sum of £5 million for current expenditure?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: In 1984, yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: What is the amount for 1985?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There is no provision for current expenditure in 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Can the Minister say if there was an application or an agreement with An Post for an annual current expenditure allocations?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The Deputy should be aware that it was acknowledged when the Posts and Telegraphs Service Bill was drawn up and was going through this House that there would be transitional difficulties between the State Department and the commercial semi-State company. For that reason provision was made in the Bill for a transitional subsidy for An Post. That will not be necessary this year or in subsequent years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Is the Minister saying that there will not be an increase in the cost of the An Post activities in the absence of this current expenditure grant from the State?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There has been no increase in the normal postal rate since I became Minister. As a result of my insistence postal volume and revenue is up. My policy is for price stability so far as possible in order to increase volume. If the volume increases sufficiently there will be adequate revenue to keep the services going.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: If there is an application during 1985 for price increases for An Post activities will the Minister replace that price increase for the consumer with the exchange subsidy that was agreed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is a hypothetical question. I do not anticipate—

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: What is the Minister's view on it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: The Minister has unwittingly misled the House by saying that there was no increase in his period as Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: In the normal stamp rate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: The Minister is using words to mislead the House. There has been an increase which has affected the airmail business particulary from Shannon Airport——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Is the Deputy asking a question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: ——and it has had detrimental effect on the business community.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Has the Deputy a question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: It is only appropriate and fair that I should inform the House and the Minister of the fact that he is misleading the House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It is not in order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: Would the Ceann Comhairle not prefer me to say it here than to the press outside tomorrow?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Deputy Leyden is being mischievous. There has been no change in the normal postal rate since I became Minister. There were recent adjustments in certain postal rates for parcels and there have been certain reductions in the postal rates to EC countries.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 15.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carey Mr. Carey
Speaker.P: In view of the Minister's reply, is he aware that this parcel postal rate increase is of the order of 90 per cent and will affect the mail order business?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There have been some adjustments in the postal rate for parcels and there have been some reductions in rates in some EC countries. We are doing very well in relation to postal rates, particularly in relation to the normal postal rate, which has not increased.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 15.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Board Telecom Éireann Capital Repayment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications if he will review as a matter of urgency the proposal in Building on Reality, 1985-1987 that Bord Telecom Éireann should make a capital repayment to the Exchequer of £180 million.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There has been no change in circumstances since the decision was taken that Bord Telecom Éireann should make contributions to the Exchequer of £50 million in 1985, £60 million in 1986 and £70 million in 1987, and I do not propose therefore to review the provision. I am, however, examining how Bord Telecom Éireann could be given credit for these payments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: In relation to the hardship this will impose on Telecom Éireann and the difficulties which will arise because Telecom Éireann will have to borrow the extra money from the Exchequer, will the Minister review the decision made in Building on Reality? Most of the policy decisions taken in Building on Reality have been changed. It would be appropriate for the Minister to review the charge on Telecom Éireann which is a charge on the public and which will create unemployment in Telecom Éireann or extra borrowing by Telecom Éireann.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The levy of £50 million, £60 million and £70 million on Bord Telecom Éireann arises directly from the decision taken by the Government during the course of 1982 about the remuneration of the debt in equity of Telecom Éireann.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: The Minister is being mischievous in his statement because no firm decisions were taken in relation to the amounts. No detailed statement was given that the amounts would be as the Minister has outlined. I accept that Telecom Éireann should make refunds to the Exchequer but only when they are in a profitable position. That was our policy and it is misleading of the Minister to inform the House that we were in favour of the £180 million clawback from Telecom Éireann. We are in favour of a refund when Telecom Éireann are in a profitable position.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I assure the Deputy that I am merely implementing the decision taken by the Government in 1982 in such a way that will be least harmful to Telecom Éireann.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not agree that this imposition is coming far earlier than it should and that the policy of the Government to which he referred was to give Telecom Éireann breathing space in order that they could start making a profit and that if this is imposed too soon it will strangle the new board by heavy interest charges too early in its career?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: There is no intention to strangle the new board. The new board will be very successful and very profitable in due course. The payment schedule which I was advised on was based on decisions made by the Deputy's Government.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Not for those years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: If the Minister is not interested in strangling the board will he agree that they will have to borrow the £50 million or £60 million necessary to pay back the money to the Exchequer? If he is not interested in strangling the board will he assure the House that they will not have to borrow the money?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Deputy Reynolds was a member of the Government that directed this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: Will the Minister correct the order? Will he assure the House that the board will not have to borrow the funds to pay back to the Exchequer?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: It is a bit much to have to take this from the Deputy who was a member of the Government when the decision was taken that equity with remuneration would be the system. I have decided on a course of repayment that will cause the least difficulty to the board.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: The Minister did not answer the question. Will he assure the House that the board will not have to borrow the money, yes or no?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: That is a matter for the board.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: Does the Minister accept that the board are on record as having stated that they will have to borrow this money? Surely the Minister will strangle this good organisation before they have had time to get off the ground.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I am merely implementing a decision taken by the Government of which the Deputy was a member.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Reynolds Mr. Reynolds
Speaker.P: How can a levy be substituted for a dividend? How can the board be made to pay a dividend if they are expected to borrow the money paid to the Exchequer?

MainHeading.RHead: Telecommunications and Postal Services Users Councils
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Telecommunications and Postal Services Users Councils.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the cost of the Users' Council for the year 1984; and the number of complaints dealt with by the council.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The former Post Office Users' Council was replaced on 5 July 1984 by a Telecommunications Users' Council and a Postal Service Users' Council. The combined cost of the users' councils for the year 1984 was £49,325 and the number of complaints dealt with was 403.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: Is the Minister satisfied with the structure of the Users' Council as it stands? I do not think the public are aware of the existence of this council, as is evidenced by the 400 complaints that have been made. Would the Minister review the work of the council so that it will become more meaningful to the consumers?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The Deputy has a point and I will consider the roles of the two councils and how they might be changed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: Does the Minister propose to review the terms of reference of the council in view of the recent extension of the Ombudsman Act whose terms of reference have been extended to complaints about telephone and telecommunications generally? What future does he see for this council?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: A certain duplication has arisen because of the new role of the Ombudsman and I am considering the implications for the council.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Air Navigation Services Office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communication the number employed in the Air Navigation Services Office on 31 December 1984; the staff ranks; the maximum salary of each rank; and the total overtime paid in 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The reply is in the form of a tabular statement which I propose to circulate in the Official Report:
Following is the statement: The number of staff serving in the Air Navigation Services Office on 31 December 1984 was 622 in the following grades:

row.entry: Maximum Annual Salary of each grade as at 31/12/84
Air Traffic Control Officer Grade I
Air Traffic Control Officer Grade II
Air Traffic Control Officer Grade III

MainHeading.P: The total amount of overtime paid in 1984 in the Air Navigation Services Office was £518,591.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: How much overtime is paid?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: In 1984 the amount was £518,591.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister not think this is out of proportion as overtime? Would it not have been possible to employ more people to do the work?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: It is very highly skilled work and a lot of it is unavoidable. We are continuing our policy of making every effort to keep overtime at a minimum.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - State Equity in Shipping Companies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the total State equity injections in B & I Steam Packet Co. Ltd. and Irish Shipping Ltd., in 1984; the dates on which the transfers were made; and whether any payments are envisaged for 1985 and the amounts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The total State equity injection in the B & I Steam Packet Co. Ltd. amounted to £6 million equity in 1984. Transfers were as follows: 4 January 1984, £1.7 million; 19 April 1984, £1 million; 14 June 1984, £1.3 million; 31 December 1984, £2 million. Total, £6 million.

The financial position of B & I is a matter of grave concern to the Government. My Department are examining proposals made by the company and I expect to be making a submission to the Government in the matter shortly. I am not in a position to say at this stage what equity, if any, will be made available to the B & I in 1985. State equity was not made available to Irish Shipping Limited in 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Is the Minister saying that no equity has been made available to B & I so far in 1985?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Not to date. The last payment of £2 million was on 31 December last.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Airports Runways Expenditure.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the total amount expended in 1984 on the main runway at Dublin Airport; and the amount expended on runway at Shannon and Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: The amount expended on the main runway at Dublin Airport in 1984 was £76,800. The amounts expended on runways at Shannon and Cork were £112,000 and £5,000, respectively.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dublin/Derry Air Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the 1984 cost of the Dublin-Derry air service; and his proposals for 1985.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: Consequent on the collapse of Avair Ltd., who had been providing the Dublin-Derry service, no subsidy moneys were paid in 1984. I recently approved a proposal from Aer Arann for the resumption of service on the route in question. It is hoped that the new service will commence on 1 April or 1 May next.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Would the Minister say how much subsidy will be made available to that service in 1985?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I am not in a position to give that information because the proposals have not been finalised. I hope they will be in the very near future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The Minister referred to a date when the services will be renewed. Surely, therefore, he must be able to give a general estimate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I would prefer not to speculate on the amount of the subsidy. As soon as the facts are available I will let the Deputy know.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Will the subsidy be more or less than in the last full year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: It will be about the same amount.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Is it envisaged that this will become an all the year round service?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell
Speaker.P: I would hope so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Communications the total borrowing made by CIE on the current side in 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Mitchell Mr. J. Mitchell

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Question. - TB Eradication Programme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Agriculture the steps he proposes to take as a matter of extreme urgency to end the impasse which has arisen between his Department and the Irish Veterinary Union so that the bovine TB eradication scheme may proceed forthwith without any further delay or disruption.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The 1985 bovine TB eradication programme commenced yesterday with the issue of test listings to those veterinary surgeons who have agreed to participate in the scheme on the terms and conditions laid down by the Government in the context of the national plan. These arrangements have the full backing of the major farming organisations. The executive of the Irish Veterinary Union, however, have decided to reject the arrangements and I understand that they are currently balloting their members on this decision.

I should like to point out that in agreeing in the present difficult financial situation to provide substantial extra funds for disease eradication the Government demonstrated their commitment to getting rid of bovine TB once and for all. However, they are not prepared to continue with the testing arrangements which have failed to achieve any progress in recent years and so in the interests of taxpayers generally and of farmers, who bear much of the burden of the disease, they have decided that the provision of extra funds should be subject to certain conditions which will give me more effective control over the operation of the eradication measures.
There is more than enough testing work available and I invite all veterinary surgeons to participate in this important national effort.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): Is the Minister aware that his uncompromising attitude in this dispute may lead to a total suspension of the scheme? My information is that in the region of only 60 or 70 vets have applied to participate in the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I should like to know what the Deputy means by “uncompromising”. I do not think taxpayers would give me any credit for being otherwise or not adopting the attitude I am adopting. The scheme has cost taxpayers here approximately £1 billion. It has also cost farmers here a vast amount of money and a great deal of hardship. What I am doing is taking control of the scheme which has worked most unsatisfactorily over the years. There has been little or no improvement over the past few years despite the vast amount of money that has been spent. I have no intention of going back on my proposal to control the scheme from beginning to end.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): Does the Minister not recognise the right of the farmer to nominate his own veterinary surgeon for testing in view of the fact that he now contributes up to 50 per cent of the total cost of the scheme?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I should like to point out to the Deputy that the farming organisations have given me their full support in what I propose to do. I do not intend to go back to the old system. The system that started yesterday will be maintained. I hope the veterinary surgeons — I believe the majority hold this view — are of the opinion that this is the right way to tackle the problem and will support us in our efforts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: Will the Minister explain to the House the reason he rejected the document issued to him by the three interested veterinary groups, including veterinary officers in his Department? Recommendations were contained in it which would be in the interest of the disease eradication programme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I did not reject that document. The principal finding of that survey carried out by the three veterinary bodies was that veterinary surgeons should have individual accountability as regards the TB eradication programme. That is the essence of the Government's proposal, individual accountability.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): Is the Minister aware that the implication is that the scheme will not proceed in the absence of co-operation from the Irish Veterinary Union?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: The scheme is proceeding. It commenced yesterday and testing will commence next week. Listings were sent out as from yesterday. I am hopeful that a sizeable number of vets, better still, that all vets, will agree to participate.
