Fifty-two offenders are at present serving sentences of penal servitude for life. The length of time served to date by these offenders is as follows:

Sixteen under 2 years; Eight from 2 to 3 years; Three from 3 to 4 years; Two from 4 to 5 years; Two from 5 to 6 years; Five from 6 to 7 years; Five from 7 to 8 years; One from 8 to 9 years; Two from 9 to 10 years; Four from 10 to 11 years; One from 13 to 14 years; One from 16 to 17 years. (This offender was on temporary release for some years but was recommitted some months ago because of a serious breach of the conditions of his temporary release).

Two from 20 to 21 years. (One of these offenders has been allowed temporary release on several occasions but has been recommitted on each occasion following breaches of conditions of temporary release. Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will give details of the social employment scheme; if any local authorities have refused or found it impracticable to participate in the scheme; and the number of persons who have so far been employed under the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Paragraph 12 of Chapter Four of Building on Reality outlined the key features of the social employment scheme. Additional details are as follows: The scheme will be operated by the National Manpower Service. The £70 wage will relate to an average two and a half days, 20 hour week. There will be flexibility in working arrangements so as to allow, for example, sponsors to operate on a week on, week off basis. Participants will be free to engage in alternative work on their days off. Participants in the scheme should, in general, be over 25 years and must be in receipt of unemployment assistance in the period immediately preceding recruitment. Participants must be unemployed for more than one year but periods during which unemployment benefit, disability benefit were received or periods of training and, within limits, temporary work, will be reckonable in calculating the year. Periods of employment under the scheme will qualify for special credited contributions in a person's social insurance record but will not reckon towards qualification for unemployment benefit.

No local authority has indicated refusal to participate in the scheme or indicated that it is impracticable to do so. A number of local authorities have expressed an interest in the scheme, but pending its commencement, have not been invited to submit formal applications. I propose to launch the scheme officially on 22 February and explanatory leaflets, etc. will be available from that time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if legislation exists which bans the use or production of the carcinogenic chemical agents benzidene, 2-naphthylamine and its salts, 4-aminodiphenyl and its salts and 4-nitrodiphenyl; and, if not, whether he will be introducing legislation in the near future to deal with these substances.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The Factories (Carcinogenic Substances) (Processes) Regulations, 1972 prohibit the manufacture, formation, use or introduction into any factory of the following substances benzidene, 2-naphthylamine, 4-aminodiphenyl and 4-nitrodiphenyl and their salts and any substances containing any of the foregoing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will make available details of current regulations governing the production and use of substances recognised as being carcinogenic; and if he is satisfied with the implementation and monitoring of these regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Current legislation administered by my Department governing carcinogens consists of the Safety in Industry Acts 1955 and 1980 in general and in addition the Factories (Asbestos Processes) Regulations, 1975; Factories (Carcinogenic Substances) (Processes) Regulations, 1972; Cellulose Solutions Regulations, 1939; Factories (Chemical Factories) Regulations, 1975; Factories (Spinning by Self Acting Mules) (Health) Regulations, 1973; European Communities (Dangerous Substances and Preparations) (Marketing and Use) Regulations, 1979; and European Communities (Dangerous Substances and Preparations) (Marketing and Use) Regulations, 1981. Monitoring of the implementation of these regulations forms part of the ongoing inspection duties of the industrial inspectorate of my Department.
